title: Billy Yank
text:
Billy Yank or Billy Yankee is the personification of the <a href="United%20States">United States</a> soldier (volunteer or Regular) during the <a href="American%20Civil%20War">American Civil War</a>. The latter part of the name is derived from "<a href="yankee">yankee</a>", a worldwide slang term for Americans, adapted by American Southerners to refer only to Americans from above the Mason-Dixon Line. Although little evidence exists to suggest that the name was used widely during the Civil War (unlike its rebel counterpart <a href="Johnny%20Reb">Johnny Reb</a>), early 20th century political cartoonists introduced 'Billy Yank' to symbolize U.S. combatants in the <a href="American%20Civil%20War">American Civil War</a> of the 1860s.
Billy Yank is usually pictured wearing a regulation U.S. Army blue wool uniform that included the fatigue blouse, a light-weight wool coat with an inside pocket and four brass buttons on the front, with a <a href="kepi">kepi</a>-style forage cap made of wool broadcloth with a rounded, flat top, cotton lining, and leather visor.
